reviewText: This is the movie that was later re-written and extended to create the unfortunately short-lived television series. The series was better, in my opinion, with better special effects and somewhat more complex characters and plotting.
summary: Original movie from which the series emerged

reviewText: What a groundbreaking series and i love this movie , the series that followed is what the future was going to be, we could only imagine in  the 80's. it was just great i can't wait  until the powers that be release this movie and the series out on DVD  Matt Frewer is just awsome as the wisecracking reporter in  the future  Edison Carter who breaks the stories with help from his friends at the network including max headroom his cyber buddy. the gadgets i just love some of them and few have already come to pass . Anyway Please Release this Movie And Series On DVD Whoever Owns the Rights  Please. If you ever do release it, Release It  with all the Max Pepsi /Coke Ads Etc.  Parrrrty Onnn Ok !

reviewText: Was happy to find copy of Max Headroom Original Story (before the DVD set was to come out) as I was sorry the series didn't continue on air, brilliant, quirky, kinda real in the not too distant future, has that Brit flavor and humor woven throughout, VHS cover was somewhat worn but intact, VHS tape itself was pristine, arrived in a timely manner.

reviewText: This 1986 sci fi post-apocalyptic comedy starts off very strange and gets stranger. This is a very weird film! Still, it's bizarre humour is really great, as the first computer-generated news presenter sends up hilarious jokes and general bizarreness. With lines like "I bet Eskimos get tired of their weather forecasts!", you get the feeling it's not traditional, every day sci fi. And you'd be right.Matt Frewer (Honey I shrunk the Kids, Short Time) is in typical oddness mode, as are the rest of the eccentric cast. The plot of the film provides for some great satirical moments involving "high" tech "view phones" and techno gobbledegook.The visuals created to make the character of Max are quite dated by today's standards (the film was made in 1986) and the short running time- 60 minutes, leaves you wanting more, but hey, it stands to repeat viewings to uncover all the weird stuff. Bizarreness at it's best.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This, the original British movie, is truly great (also very funny, very scary, very prophetic) - it is archetypal cyberpunk, and was hugely influential, even outside the sci-fi/hacker/geek world. It could perhaps be described as Blade Runner meets Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy. The music video series that preceded it was weird and funny, the interview show (which I haven't seen) sounds intriguing (especially the William Shatner interview!), and the US series actually lived up to the movie.But - I've searched all over the internet for Max Headroom on DVD, and all I can find are choruses of people wailing "Why isn't this on DVD?"  When the big brains who own the shows actually put them out on DVD, they're going to make a mint.(Taps foot impatiently...)Meanwhile, this will do as a stop-gap. Watch and wonder.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Maximun Headroom here is a malfunctioningcomputer character based on Matt Frewer's 'reallife' in this Pilot originally cast for the BBC.Frewer, a Canadian-American is the only non-britin here and the lovely Amanda Pays by herself isworth a watch by herself! Spawned the short-lived,but well-made t.v. series which coincided with theshort-lived and tragically bad 'new coke'. But I'dtrade the (Nutri-)poison diet coke for new cokeany day!
summary: [Three-and-a-half stars out of four] ..."Make Room for Max. Headroom..."
